speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: We'll hear argument first this morning in Samson versus California. Mr. Long.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Mr. Long --

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Mr. Long --

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: -- with respect to liberty, as it -- it's not disputed, is it, that your client could have had his parole revoked even though the search was suspicionless? So, what we're talking about the difference between revocation of parole, on the one hand, and a separate criminal offense. Is that right?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: But I thought that evidence seized could be introduced, could be a basis to revoke parole.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: So, the -- what the -- the consequence here is whether -- 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: -- he will have his parole revoked --

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: -- or he will have a separate criminal offense.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Well, Justice Ginsburg, I suppose, can pursue her own line of questioning, but let me ask you this, because I -- her question suggests this, to me at least. Suppose the parole officer said, "Now, look, I'm going to search you. If you don't consent, then I'm going to revoke your parole."

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: I -- my question was a parole officer, and I'll get to police officer next. 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: When you see the --

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: -- person on the street, et cetera, et cetera.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Why are they dire? I mean, he's just back in the situation he would have been in, did he not comply with the conditions of his parole. I don't see that that's dire. He has a choice. He can stay in prison and --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: -- and suffer the reduction 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 of privacy there, which is much, much greater than being subjected to -- I mean, he -- he cannot even go to the toilet in privacy. Or he can go out on parole, subject to the condition that --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: -- that he --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: -- he can --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: -- be searched.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: No, but it's --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: -- but it's also clear from the California statute that it is not a right, that it's a privilege, that you get the privilege of parole in exchange -- in exchange for agreeing to the conditions, one of which is that you can be searched.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: California statute says it's a privilege, doesn't it?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: It does.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Even if the --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: -- prisoner -- oh, I thought that he can turn it down, and that some prisoners do, if --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: -- if they decide that they don't want to be subjected to searches.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Is -- and you mean people are put out on the street when -- kicking and screaming 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 when they say, "No, I want to stay in jail. I don't want to be" --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: -- "searched. I would rather stay in jail"? And --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: -- they are dragged out --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: -- into the street. Is that what happens?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Oh, I --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: -- I don't think so.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Well, but --

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: -- their condition is very different, in a broad range of areas. They -- you give up First Amendment rights. For example, it's typical to have a condition of parole that you don't consort with known criminals or gang members. You -- often it says you must refrain from alcohol. Sometimes they say you can't go near particular places, if they think that's going to tempt you to return to a life of crime. Those are all First Amendment rights that are sacrificed while you're on parole. Why is this any different?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: What about a drug -- what if you're convicted of a drug offense, you're on parole, and one of the conditions is, every week you have to go in for a drug test?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Do you --

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: -- do you -- is that acceptable?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: But it would be a Fourth Amendment right that you would be giving up --

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: -- that you would otherwise have if you weren't on parole.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: What would you say about a condition that you must -- not a regular drug test -- you just have to submit yourself to a drug test whenever a police officer asks you to?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Well, but it's -- I mean, the point --

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: Do you think it would valid? That's what I was asking you.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Well, so that a --

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: -- so that a burglar could be searched for burglar tools --

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: -- but not for drugs? And the drug addict can be searched for drugs, and not burglar tools?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: But Justice Stevens's question highlights the point that you criticize about: 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 the randomness of it is often a critical element. I suppose it makes much more sense to say you're subject to a random drug test than that you have to come in at a scheduled time, when you -- presumably, you could refrain from using drugs prior to the test. And, to some extent, it's the same, even if you're not talking about a drug test.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: The search is only going to be effective if it's not announced or --

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: -- scheduled.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Are you relying --

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: -- on the difference between -- you said "officer in the field." Would this be okay if it had been his parole officer?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: The parole officer was walking along the street, saw this guy, and said, "I'm going to search you."

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: When he's in prison, is there any problem about the prison guards intruding upon his privacy, willy-nilly, whenever they choose?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: I mean, walking --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: -- by his cell, which is always opened, and checking in on him to see what's -- what he's doing.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: So, he's better off on parole than -- well, at least no worse off on parole than he would be when he was in prison.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Are --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: What --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Not --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: -- what do you make of -- 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: -- by me. No, please.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: What do you make of the pragmatic argument that seems to cut through all of your objections? The pragmatic argument is both in favor of complete discretion and of suspicionless search, that the in terrorem effect of knowing that these searches can occur at any moment, in fact, discourages recidivism.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: What's your response to that?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Apart from --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Apart from the lack of popularity of the State's view --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: -- do we have -- do we have any empirical evidence that bears on the in terrorem 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 argument?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: No, I --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: -- I realize that. But, beyond that, do we have any empirical evidence, one way or the other?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: I take it --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: -- the answer is --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: -- we don't have any empirical evidence, one way or the other, apart from the fact that California stands out in its system. Is that correct?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: No, I --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: -- I know it, but I've said, about three times, that I want to get beyond the peculiar position of California to any other empirical evidence that cuts for you or against you. And I take it there really isn't --

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Why --

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Well --

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Why, if we're going to catch some additional people, is that not sufficient? That is, why is it unreasonable, say, not for law professors, but business school professors, management consultants, to say, "You have a lot of prisoners in 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 California, hundreds of thousands -- I don't know, maybe more than 100,000 -- and we'll tell the Legislature that they can cut the terms, save money, release them early, but we want to have management checks. And the management checks are, you might be searched at any time. And we catch a few. And that's helpful." Now, if the --

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: -- State decides that, what's unreasonable about it? "They're" --

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: -- "letting the people out earlier than they otherwise would" --

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: -- says the Legislature.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: And what's on the other side? The other side --

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: -- is, you'd rather not have policemen search you, but your alternative is going to be in jail.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: But, of course, that's how it happens when he's in prison.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: But there is a breathtakingly high probability that he is committing a crime. The statistics cited in the Government's brief say that in an April 2001 report prepared by the California Criminal Justice Statistics Center, 68 percent of adult parolees are returned to prison -- 68 percent; 55 percent, for a parole violation; and 13 percent for the commission of a new felony offense. I mean, it seems to me a breathtaking statistic like that may call for breathtaking --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: -- measures to try to police the matter closely.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Well, the --

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: -- California --

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: The California Supreme Court said that the Fourth Amendment applied to these searches, but it only protected in a limited way, 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 along the same lines as we said in Griffin. And the standard they applied was, it protected against arbitrary or harassing or capricious searches --

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: -- which seems to go to your argument, which is centered around the unbridled discretion of the officer. And the California Supreme Court is saying it's not unbridled.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Well, that's --

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: -- fine. But it turns out he stops the guy every hour of the day, then he has a pretty strong case that this is for 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 harassment, and it's not --

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: -- for the special law enforcement --

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: -- need that accompanies releasing parolees.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: No, but your point was that this is the core of the Fourth Amendment, and they're taking away all of the protection and leaving it to the unbridled discretion. And that turns out to be not the case. Under the law that authorizes the procedure, the California Supreme Court interpretation is that the Fourth Amendment provides protection against harassment or arbitrary and --

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: -- capricious searches.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Then which way do you think that cuts? There's --

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: -- never been a case of a harassing search of a parolee.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: I mean, that's what - - or 200 cases in the --

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Why?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Why? If it -- if it -- if it -- it doesn't go to the suspicionless character of the search, but it does say it has to be reasonable in time, place, or manner.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: And maybe the --

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: -- officers are reasonable in time, place --

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: -- or manner.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: How many times has it been challenged --

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: -- on the --

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: Well -- 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: You say there was a case in which, without any special reason, they did --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: -- a cavity search --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: The California Supreme Court may -- might well hold that it's arbitrary to conduct such an extreme search as a body-cavity search, or to - - I don't know --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: -- to decide to search the person when he's in the men's room or something. I mean, there are --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: -- there are a lot of limitations that the California court --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: -- could put on it, within the context of harassment or --

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: But the reason ---

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: -- the reason that people, I think, are saying that is because they have a lot of prisoners, they're trying to create a category of people who don't have to stay in prison, where they have no rights. And the real question is, can California, in trying to create this interim category, reduce the Fourth Amendment right in the way you describe?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Of course they can't do it, but the justification is not that there is something bad about this particular individual or he's in some kind of limbo. The reason is that there's a policy tending towards release, which California has decided they want to introduce this as a condition. Now --

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: -- and so, what -- and the 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 question is, what's unreasonable about that?

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: May I -- may I ask you --

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: -- this question? Part of your appeal of your case is, you talk about the corporate offender or tax dodger, something like that. It seems quite unreasonable, I agree with you. But what if you defined the class much more narrowly and limit it to people who have been convicted of violent crimes of a very serious nature and so forth, and said, as to those, they can have a totally suspicionless search? Would that --

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: -- be permissible?

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: But I wonder whether -- 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: -- whether you think they could do that.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: Well, what I'm --

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: I wanted to see if there is a way that the class could be defined narrowly, because I want to ask the other side if they would allow the search for any ex-felon, for example. You could divide it in a way that seemed obviously too broad. But is --

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: -- there a narrower class - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: -- that you think would be acceptable?

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: Say you were a -- 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 --

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: -- terrorist, for example.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: It's just limited to terrorists, convicted terrorists.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: What about drug offenders, given the high rate of recidivism?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Mr. Long, is it -- is it fair to compare California to other States? The assumption would have to be that other States grant parole as liberally as California does. Maybe California has made the decision, "We have too many people in prison. We're going to let a lot of them 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 -- out, but we're going to keep them on a very tight leash." Why shouldn't it be able to do that? To have tighter controls, but let out many more people on parole, which is -- which is exactly what I think they're doing.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: But my only --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: -- point is --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: -- the fact that other States aren't as tight doesn't prove anything, because other States --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: -- may not be --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: -- be trying to do the same thing --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: -- to empty their prisons --

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Suppose you were in a halfway house, and the State says, "We're creating a status. One is, you're a prisoner. Another is, you're a halfway house. Another is, on your -- parole. But we want to subject you to suspicionless searches at -- in all three stages -- prison, halfway house, parole." Could they do it for the halfway house?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: This person goes --

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: -- out to work, comes back at the end of the day, and is checked in.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Yes, while the -- 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: -- while the --

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: The person who is in this semi-custody state, he's going to work, and, while he's at his workplace, the police officer shows up and says, "I'm going to pat you down, and then I'm going to" --

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: -- "see if you have drugs."

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thank you, Mr. Long. Mr. Niver, we'll hear now from you.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Why is that? Doesn't that kind of beg the question? I mean, if we say he's got the normal Fourth Amendment rights, his -- I mean, the expectation-of-privacy analysis seems to me to be totally circular.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: You say he doesn't have an expectation of privacy, so it's not protected. Well, if we say he does have a -- if we say it is protected, then he does have an expectation of privacy. 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Well, Knights involved a situation where reasonable suspicion was required, so it addressed the problem that Mr. Long has of unbridled discretion. You still had to have an articulable reasonable suspicion with respect to the individual.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Why -- and why was his expectation of privacy severely diminished?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Because of the very practice that's being challenged here today, right?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Because he saw something -- you -- he signed something that said, "You're subject to searches." Well, that's what is at issue. It seems to me that it's -- I guess I've said it before, he's -- it's begging the question to say, "You can do this, because he has a diminished expectation of privacy." How far do you push this? Can you have parolees come in and take a lie-detector test every week? Do they have -- do they have diminished expectation with respect to their Fifth Amendment rights?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Was that a yes, you 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 can have them --

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: You can.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Is --

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: What about --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Is --

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: What about --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Is that right? I mean, even in prison, I -- what -- I'm not sure you could even do that if they were still in prison. Can you subject people in prison --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: No. No, I --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: The Chief Justice was trying to get out of the Fourth Amendment into the Fifth.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: Would you say the same thing if the offense he had committed was tax evasion or price-fixing or speeding? Would the -- would a person on parole for any one of those offenses have -- be subject to the same risk of a suspicionless search? And would it be justified?

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: Well --

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: -- applying this statute to

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: -- a price-fixer, tax- evader, speeder. Do you think it's justified?

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: And if it's to be --

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: -- applied to the tax offender and so forth, how about just applying it to all ex-felons? Would that be permissible?

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: No, just the very fact that there's -- they're an ex-felon. And let the person know, at the time of his discharge from prison, that this is one of the things that the State is going to exact from you as a punishment for your crime.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: No, I'm saying --

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: -- he's not on parole.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: But I'm hypothesizing a case in which the law will destroy the expectation of privacy, because it will provide that all ex-felons are subject to search. So, they would know, the same as a parolee now knows, he's subject to search. Would that be valid?

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: But -- so you don't --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Most --

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: -- rely on --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Most States --

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: -- the fact that --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: -- don't let felons vote. I mean, that's a punishment that they impose after they're out of prison.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: But then we're not relying on the elimination of the expectation of privacy, because, under my hypothetical statute, the ex-felon would know he's subject to it. So, it has to be something other than the absence of an expectation of privacy. Is that correct?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: It seems to me that the 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 principal difference, Mr. Niver, is that when he's on parole, it's in lieu of being in jail. If that's not the difference, you don't persuade me. He has voluntarily accepted the parole in exchange for his getting out of jail. And he'd be in worse condition if he were in jail. That's what, seems to me, makes the difference.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Mr. Niver --

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: But what do you achieve by this system that you have that you couldn't achieve by a system that more carefully worked out the rules and conditions of a random search? I mean, rules, so that you avoid the totally discretionary element. And if you want to have management consultants, as I was 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 imagining, have 'em. They're not just going to tell you, "Go and ask anybody to search anytime he wants." They'll have a system worked out. So, why not at least require you to think it through that much? And, otherwise, it is unreasonable.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Well, are there manuals -- are there any -- here is the cop on the beat.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: He sees someone that he knows is a parolee. Is there any instruction that he's been given so that his discretion can be guided instead of rudderless? In practice in California, are all --

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Yes. What is the practice?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: I'm asking you about what instruction, what training, if you know, are officers given? Or are they given no training, just the law 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 that says, "You can search any parolee"?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Okay. The officer says, "I'm searching to see whether the person has any evidence of crime on him." For example, whether he has any drugs on him. Law enforcement purpose: supervisory, I suppose. They want to know whether their -- whether their parolees are committing offenses. And yet, that reason would apply to everyone virtually all the time. So, it doesn't seem to be a limitation at all. What -- am I -- am I missing something?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Well, how does the limitation work? The guy is on 1st Street, and an officer says, you know, "I recognize this person is a parolee, and I have a law enforcement objective. Is the person committing a crime? Is the -- is the person a recidivist? Is the person violating parole?" So, he 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 searches him. The person gets to 2nd Street, another officer does the same thing. Three hours later, a third officer does the same thing. In each case, it seems to me, their justification would not fall afoul of the arbitrary, capricious, or harassment standard. It's not coordinated. They have a -- both a parole and a law enforcement objective. Why is there any limitation, then, on the right to search?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Uh-huh.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: No. No, but let's get behind the rhetoric. Is there any reason my hypothetical could not, in fact, turn out to be true?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Apart from the unlikelihood of all those police officers out there. But, leaving that aside, is there -- is there any reason, in the standard, that my hypothetical could not be true?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Okay. I mean, let's assume the police are telling the truth, and the judge says, "Sure." So, there is no limitation. And it sounds to me, then, as though about the only limitation that would be enforceable would be the limitation against harassment. If one officer did it every 15 minutes to the same person, or if there were a departmental systematic policy saying, you know, "Get so-and-so," that I can understand as being a limitation. But I don't see any other limit.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: No, I realize --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: -- but do you --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: -- do you agree that there is not any practical limitation, other than the 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 harassment limitation?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Well, maybe --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: -- maybe it is. But what's the answer to my question? Is that, in practical terms, the only limitation?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Okay.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: I thought you said that maybe cavity searches would not -- would not be allowed without some special reason for them. And that wouldn't necessarily be harassment.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Yes --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: I mean --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Okay. 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: What would be arbitrary and capricious? You told us harassing would be the repeated searches by the same officer.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Well, let's assume -- let's assume that the cavity search is demanded at the bus station, and the officer says, "We know that drugs get transported by people who ingest them in the balloons, and they get on buses and they travel back and forth from city A to city B." Any reason that that would run afoul of arbitrary and capricious?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: All I'm telling you is, he's at a bus station. The facts are that a lot of people who travel on buses are drug couriers. This person is a parolee. Would that run afoul of the -- of any arbitrary and capricious limitation?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Well, sure, but the officer says, "All right. I'm taking you down to the station for a cavity search."

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Well, you're -- I'm asking you to be the finder of fact for me. This is the officer's explanation. This is the factual -- set of factual premises on which he acts. Has he violated the arbitrary and capricious limitation?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: I have one --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Well, suppose you couldn't - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: I have one --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: -- you couldn't --

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: I have --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: -- conduct cavity searches 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 without some special reason, even in prison. Wouldn't that be -- isn't there some remnant of a fourth- amendment right in prison that you cannot subject, you know, the whole cellblock to cavity searches?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Well, I --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: -- I thought the assumption of your answer to my question a moment ago was that there was no such limitation, so far as California is concerned.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Well, sure. But we -- the manner, in this case, is, they take him down to the station, so that they're not going through this in the middle of a crowded bus terminal. But the point of the question was, any parolee at a bus terminal could be subjected to this demand for search, and I thought your answer was, yes, he could be. And now, in response to Justice Scalia's question, you're saying, "Well, there may be some limitation." So, which is it?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Does it depend -- I mean, what if he's on parole for transporting drugs in balloons from bus stations? Does that make a difference? -- as opposed to, he's on parole for tax fraud.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: But all this is on a case -- would be on a case-by-case basis. There are no going-in guides for the officer on the street.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Do we --

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: But the reasonableness here would be unreasonable, unless there are some checks. We're talking about suspicionless searches. And you could have checks. But what about saying -- why is it 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 reasonable to do it without any rule-based controls on the behavior of the police? That's the question.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Okay. But what interest does it serve not to have some rules, manuals, regulations that help make sure it really is random, or help make sure it isn't harassing, or help make sure that it's serving the very ends that you hope to serve with the suspicionless searches?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thank you, Mr. Niver. Mr. Marcus.

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: Do we have --

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: But not the consent -- 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: -- to decide --

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: -- not the consent approach, I take it. I didn't get an opportunity to ask the counsel who argued just previously. Seemed to me that he argued consent when he answered Justice Stevens's question about the tax-evader. But he argued the overwhelming practical needs when he argued the rest of the case. And I thought I saw some tension in the argument there. And I take it the Government does not embrace the consent argument?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: But you --

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: -- just --

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: -- put it in number --

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: -- you put it --

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: -- in number three?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: In --

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: But in your view, if the consent was straightforward in the documents, would that be the strongest argument or the weakest argument?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: I mean, I take you'll win on any --

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: -- argument --

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: -- you can take.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Mr. Long seemed to have -- tell us something different about that. It's -- they had -- they must go out. He seemed to say they didn't have the choice of staying in.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: I think he said he was unaware of anybody who was dragged out kicking and 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 screaming.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: But it really --

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: -- it really isn't.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: It's -- this is not like you sign an agreement and you're -- you can do it or you can not do it. I mean, this is a real Hobson's choice, isn't it?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: You can't --

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: -- negotiate, "I don't" --

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: -- "want this part."

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Could you --

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: -- waive your -- could you waive --

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: -- your Eighth Amendment rights? You know, if your parole's revoked, you're going to go back into a very cruel and unusual prison, not the one you left.

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: What if it's the case --

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: -- that this program would 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 allow some searches that are -- that violate the Fourth Amendment, but that this particular search would not? How closely can we focus just on what happened here, or do we have to consider all the -- all the types of searches and the circumstances of searches that the California program might permit?

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: But following --

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: -- up on Justice --

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: -- Alito's thought, supposing there were no restrictions whatsoever, but this particular search didn't seem very offensive. Would you still defend it?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: No.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: He's asking you, I think, Justice Alito's question, "Do we have to get into that?" So long as this one's okay, why do -- why do we have to get into whether there might be some other ones that aren't okay?

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: And it --

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: -- it was assumed California --

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: -- didn't say if they had protection against harassment and so forth. Suppose they just said, "Cart blanche, you can search any parolee at any time, any place." And then you'd ask whether this search was reasonable.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: So, it would uphold this.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: There's --

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: -- no matter now unreasonable the California statute might be in other applications. 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: The Government -- is the Government of the United States somewhat behind the State of California? It's not efficient in -- as efficient as California in supervising its parolees? Because you don't have this rule.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Has --

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: -- the recidivism rate gone down in the years since the Reyes decision, since this is suspicionless search, as opposed to reasonable suspicion?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Do --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Even apart from the -- what -- the lack of evidence for any change since the Reyes decision, do we have any empirical evidence, perhaps involving a control group, about the likelihood of the -- this liberal search policy in reducing recidivism?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Go ahead.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thank you, Mr. Marcus. Mr. Long, you have 2 minutes remaining.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: But we --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: -- we normally don't look into the mind of the officer to decide whether his action was okay or not.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thank you, Mr. Long. The case is submitted. [Whereupon, at 11:18 a.m., the case in the above-entitled matter was submitted.] 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400
